dialogues.text: The receptionist waves Hoke in and he proceeds down the corridor to

dialogues.speaker: MISS MCCLATCHEY'S DESK
dialogues.text: where she is seated, typing letters. Boolie's voice is HE on the DICTAPHONE machine by her side. She types as fast he talks. When she sees Hoke she smiles, turns off her machine. : MCCLATCHEY . Well, good morning to you.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Can I see him?

dialogues.speaker: MCCLATCHEY
dialogues.text: He's out there with the construction. Best toy he ever had.  74.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: I know that's the truth. ‘He walks back down the hall and through the FACTORY, which looks pretty much as it did fourteen years before, past the same old FREIGHT ELEVATOR with the same old corrugated tin door. Oscar, older now, is unloading full hand carts.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Hey, my man!

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: They ain' give you a new elevator yet?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: You don't see one, do you?

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Well all right. He proceeds through the factory and out a rear door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The early stages of construction. Concrete poured on firs floor and I-beams being put in place. Boolie, wearing har hat and expensive suit, talking to CONSTRUCTION WORKERS. Boolie is a bit paunchier and balder.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: Eddie, are you telling me you're going over already?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: No suh, Mist' Werthan. I'm just sayin' be prepared, if you git my meanin'.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: I'm prepared to spend exactly what's in the contract and not one dime more.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I hear you. Boolie sees Hoke. He moves away from the construction gro

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (to a worker as Boolie moves away) They don't call 'em Jews for nothing.  75. The other man snickers.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: (to Hoke) Isn't it your day off? To what do I owe this honor?

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Seein' ‘bout things in the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: Well, let me show you around. They move around to a

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: (pointing up at empty air) Right there's gonna be my office. One hell of a view.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Isn't that something?

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: You don't seem real interested. .

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: We got to talk, Mr. Werthan.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: It Mist' Sinclair Harris.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: My cousin Sinclair?

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: His wife.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: Jeanette? :

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: The one talk funny.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: She’s from Canton, Ohio.  76.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Yassuh. She tryin' to hire me.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: ‘She phone when she know Miz Daisy be out and she say, "How are they treating you, Hoke?" You know how she soun', like her nose stuff up. And I say, "Fine, Miz Harris," and she say, "Well, if you lookin' for a change, you know where to call."

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: I'll be damned!

dialogues.speaker: BROKE
dialogues.text: I thought you want to know ‘bout it.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: I'll be God damned!

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Ain' she a mess? (a pause) She say name yo sal'ry.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: I see. And did you?

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Did I what?

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: Name your salary.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Now, what you think I am? I ain' studyin' workin' for no trashy somethin' like her.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: But she got you to thinkin', didn't she? :

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: You might could say dat.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: Come on back in my office. They head back inside the factory.  77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same space as before, but serious redecoration has occurred. It is now furnished with the latest blonde maho desk, coffee table, side piece, etc. The wall-to-wall carpeting and drapes are new, too. And there is a new fas photo of Florine placed prominently. She has Mamie Eisenh bangs in it. Boolie sits at his desk, puts his feet up an motions Hoke to sit.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: Name your salary.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Dat what she say.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: Well, how does $65 a week sound?

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Sound pretty good. ‘Course seventy- five sounds better.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: So it does. Beginning this week.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Das mighty nice of you, Mist' Werthan. I 'preciate it. Mist' Werthan, you ever had people fightin’ over you?

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Well, I tell you. It feel good. He smiles and walks happily out of the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only addition to the scene is a bulky console b/w TELEVIS set, which is ON at the moment, a soap opera in progress. Idella and Hoke are watching avidly. Idella is shelling p a paper bag for the pods and a bowl for the peas. She loo very old and frail. Daisy stops in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I don't know how y'all can look at that.  78.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: you see it a few times, you get in t.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Your brains are gonna dry up. I'll be up in my room reading. Don't make a mess with those peas, Idella.

dialogues.speaker: IDELLA
dialogues.text: Do I ever? Daisy goes upstairs. The two watch.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Ain't the blonde one got a lotta hair? How do she make it so shiny?

dialogues.speaker: IDELLA
dialogues.text: (shelling away) Washes it in my-naise. He looks dubious.

dialogues.speaker: IDELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes she do. Had about it in Life Magazine. : “HOKE Don' seem human, do it?

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SOAP OPERA
dialogues.text: Two young women drinking coffee in a kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: DARK-HAIRED YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: Virginia, I saw Richard last night. Ominous organ MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: DARK-HAIRED YOUNG WOMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It looked to me like he was on his way to Hope's house! More ominous MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Look out! Linda up to somethin’ now. What you think, Idella? No answer.  79.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Idella? 0.S. SOUND of BOWL hitting the floor. We ‘SEE the bowl overturned and peas rolling out on the Oriental rug.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Idella! Idella!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a fairly small church, humble in contrast to Dais Temple we have seen earlier. The sanctuary is about half- filled at the moment. A funeral is in progress. A BLACK CHOIR MEMBER - A TEEN-AGED GIRL, with a particula strong voice, is singing "What a Friend we Have in Jesus. She wears a choir robe. She is standing with the rest of choir, but this is the solo part of the service. A MINISTER, also black and also robed, stands nearby, jus behind a simple coffin. A SHOT OF THE SANCTUARY reveals that the entire populatio black, except for three white people in the rear -- Daisy Boolie and Florine. Hoke is sitting in the pew with them, the aisle, next to Boolie. Everyone in the congregation h a printed program of events. ON THE THREE WHITE FACES, a part of the service, but not part. Florine wears a stylish suit, Daisy has on a black with a veil. She looks straight ahead at the singer, her showing no emotion. Only Hoke's face expresses his feelin as the four watch the solemn proceedings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time, the kitchen looks a bit out of date, shabby. The linoleum is clean, but a little chipped and scruffy. An electric fry pan sits on one of the counters, . Clearly a concession to Boolie because it is shiny new ebviously never used. - Daisy is frying chicken in a large black cast iron skille The cut-up chicken is on the counter as is the paper bag of flour. She shakes the chicken in the bag, then places in the hot oil skillet. Hoke appears behind her, watching critically. Eventually cannot contain himself and speaks.  80.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: You fixin' to ruin it.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: You got de skillet turn up too high and de chicken too close together.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Mind your business.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: It's yo' chicken. He shrugs, walks out of the kitchen. Daisy considers a Moment, turns the flame down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some time later. Daisy, wearing gardening gloves, is stan on a small kitchen stepladder, wielding a large pair of shears, trimming a shrub. Hoke stands at the foot of: the ladder, picking up the clippings and putting them in a ne wheelbarrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING SHOT of ice storm in progress, branches weig down, icicles hanging everywhere, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Effects of storm visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No furniture or decoration has changed here since we firs it, but everything is older. Daisy is on her knees rummag through the lowest commode drawer. Outside the storm is visible. The hall is dark. Daisy finds what she is lookin for, a stumpy old white candle. She shuts the drawer, get up, and we FOLLOW HER through THE DARK PANTRY into

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: somewhat lighter because of the windows. She lights the candle with kitchen matches, drips wax onto a saucer, and firms the candle in place. She heads back towards the liv room.  81. She walks through the dark HALL. We FOLLOW HER into

dialogues.speaker: THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Only a little brighter, evidence of ice storm outside. Th room seems more cluttered, less organized than it was in And the darkness of the morning only accentuates the some shabby aura. Daisy goes to sit in her armchair. The current National Geographic is on the table. She picks it up and tries to read, but is unsuccessful in the poor light. Suddenly she HEARS the BACK DOOR open and close. FOOTSTEP She half-rises out of the chair in alarm.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: HOKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mornin', Miz Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Oh, Hoke. She sinks back into her chair with relief. Hoke comes int the doorway. She is carrying a paper bag, and wears an evercoat and galoshes. .

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: What in the world?

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: I learn to drive on ice when I deliver milk for the Avondale Dairy. Ain' much to it. I slip aroun' a little comin' down Briarcliff, but nothin' happen. Other folks bangin' into each other like they in the funny papers, tho'. Oh, I stop at” the 7-11. I figure yo' stove out and Lawd knows you got to have yo’ coffee in the morning. She is touched.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: How sweet of you, Hoke! He hands her a cardboard cup and sips his own.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: We ain' had no good coffee 'roun heah since Idella pass.  82.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Mmm Hmm. iI can fix her biscuits and we both know how to make her fried chicken. But nobody can make Idella's coffee. I wonder how she did it.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: I doan' nome. They sip silently for a moment, deep in thoughts. Then:

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Idella was lucky.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Yassum. I ‘spec she was. He starts out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Put desheah things up. Take off my overshoes.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I didn't think you'd come today.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: What you mean? It ain' my day off, is it? :

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Boolie called and said he couldn't even get down his driveway. Well, I don't know what you can do around here except keep me company.

dialogues.speaker: . HOKE
dialogues.text: I see can I light us a fire. He leaves the room. The next few exchanges are Daisy call to him in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Eat anything you want out of the ice box. It'll all spoil anyway.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yassum.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: And wipe up what you tracked onto my kitchen floor.  83.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Now, Miz Daisy, what you think I am? A mess? This is an old routine between them and not without affec Daisy smiles. The PHONE RINGS, loudly. An intrusion on th ntimacy. Daisy gets up to answer. She speaks as she goes to the ha

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Yes. That's exactly what I think you are.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: All right den. All right.

dialogues.speaker: THE HALL TELEPHONE
dialogues.text: (NOTE: The scene of following phone conversation shifts between Daisy's hall and BOOLIE'S DEN, where he sits wear cashmere sweater and a muffler. Florine can also be seen, wearing a full-length mink coat and expensive leather glo

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll all be melted by this afternoon. They said so on the radio. I'll be out after you as soon as I can get down the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Stay where you are, Boolie. Hoke is here with me.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: How in the hell did he manage that?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: He's very handy. I'm fine. I don't need a thing in the world.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: Hello? (to Florine) I must have the wrong number. I never heard Mama say loving things about Hoke before.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I didn't say I love him. I said he was handy.  84.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: (winking at Florine) Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: . DAISY
dialogues.text: Honestly, Boolie. Are you trying to irritate me in the middle of an ice storm? She hangs up sharply. ON BOOLIE as he hangs up the phone, smiling at his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A traffic jam is in progress. Cars standing still, HORNS BLARING, irritability in the air. It is early fall, but h and humid. One of the cars in the stalled lane is Daisy's. It's a ca haven't seen before -- a Cadillac sedan (circa 1960). All Daisy's cars, subsequent to the first Cadillac, are virtu the same -- all "Cadillac blue" -- but, of course, Boolie trades them in every two or three years -- a matter of eq At the moment Daisy is alone in her car, fanning herself her handkerchief, and out of sorts. She is wearing a hat gloves. Hoke, walking against the traffic, reaches Daisy's car. H earrying his jacket. He leans into the car.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Well, what is it? You took so long!

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Couldn't help it. Big mess up yonder.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: What's the matter? I might as well not go to Temple at all now! He gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: You cain' go to Temple today, Miz Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Why not? What in the world is the matter with you?  85.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Somebody done bomb the Temple.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: What? Bomb the Temple!

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Yassum. Dat why we stuck here so long.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I don't believe it!

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Dat what the policeman tell me up yonder. Say it happen about a half hour ago.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Oh, no! Oh, my God! Well, was anybody there? Were people hurt?

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Din’ say.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Who would do such a thing?

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: You know good as me. Always be the same ones.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Well, it's a mistake. I'm sure they meant to bomb one of the Conservative synagoges or the Orthodox one. The Temple is Reform. Everybody knows that. HOKE . It doan matter to them people. A Jew is a Jew to them folks. Jes' like light or dark, we all the same nigger.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I can't believe it!

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Tell you what. I see can I get us out of here. He starts up the car, maneuvers it down the shoulder of t road, moving past all the congestion.  86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy's car moving in lighter traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoke drives. Daisy dabs at her eyes with a Kleenex.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: I know jes' how you feel, Miz Daisy. Back down there above Macon on the farm -- I ‘bout ten or ‘leven years old -- and one day my frien’ Porter, his Daddy hangin' from a tree. And the day befo', he laughin’ and pitchin' horseshoes wid us. Talkin' ‘bout Porter and me gon' have good strong right arms like him. And den he hangin' up yonder wid his hands tie behind his back an' the flies all over him. And I seed dat with my own eyes and I threw up right where I was standin'. You go on an' cry.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I'm not crying. (after a moment of collecting herself) why did you tell me that story?

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: I doan' know. Seem like disheah mess put me in mind of it.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Ridiculous! The Temple has nothing to do with that!

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: So you say.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: We don't even know what happened. How do you know that policeman was telling you the truth?

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: Now, why would a policeman go and lie "bout a thing like dat?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Well, you never get things right anyway.  87.

dialogues.speaker: . HOKE
dialogues.text: Miz Daisy, somebody done bomb dat Place and you know it, too. DAISY . Go on. Just go on now. I don't want to hear any more about it.

dialogues.speaker: HOKE
dialogues.text: You de boss.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Stop talking to me! ON HOKE'S sad, compassionate face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1966 The entire top floor of a mid-sixties Atlanta skyscraper a panoramic view. This is a businessman's club/restaurant furnished appropriately with leather chairs, paneled wall portraits of past presidents, etc. There is an honorary luncheon in progress. Boolie, the honoree, sits at the center of a raised table on a dais. to him is Florine, dressed in a fashionable mini-dress an Courreges white boots. Next to her is Daisy in her best dress. . WELLBORN ARKWRIGHT, the president of the Commerce Club, i standing in his place, on the other side of Florine, hold large engraved silver bowl, and beckoning to Boolie. Gene applause. Boolie rises, takes the trophy, and approaches microphone. A cameraman gets off a few shots.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Wellborn. And thank you all. I am deeply grateful to be chosen Man of the Year by the Atlanta Business Council -- an honor I've seen bestowed on some mighty fine fellas and which I certainly never expected to come to me. I'm afraid the loss here -- (he touches his hair) -- and the gain here -- (he pats his belly) -- have given me an air of competence I don't possess. But I'll tell you, I sure wish my father and grandfather could see this. Seventy-two years ago they opened a little hole-in-the-wall shop on Whitehall Street with one printing press. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They managed to grow with Atlanta and to this day, the Werthan Company believes we want what Atlanta wants. This award proves we must be right. Thank you. He holds up his trophy. Applause. He starts back to his s but thinks better of it.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One more thing. If the Jackets whup the Dogs up in Athens Saturday afternoon, I'll be a completely happy man. Laughs, lighter applause. Boolie shakes Wellborn's hand, goes back to his place. He kisses a delighted Florine. Another flash bulb or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy is seated at the telephone table, dialing. Still th same old black telephone. She dials with some difficulty. Things have become harder for her to do.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Hidey, Miss McClatchey. You always recognize my voice. What a shame a wonderful girl like you never married. Miss McClatchey, is my son in? Oh, no no no. Please don't call him out of a sales meeting. Just give him a message. Tell him I bought the tickets for the UJA banquet. Yes, UJA banquet ‘honoring Martin Luther King on the seventeenth. Well, you're a sweet thing to say so. And don't you worry. My cousin Tillie in Chattanooga married for the first time at fifty-seven. ‘Bye. She places the phone in its cradle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boolie comes through the back door on his way home from w The end of the same day. The house is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: Mama? Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Up here.  89. He follows her voice up the stairs into

dialogues.speaker: HER BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Daisy sits at her desk, paying bills. Her large, old- fashioned checkbook open on her desk and a small stack of bills neatly stacked and stamped nearby. She works efficiently, but slowly, because it's harder to write now She continues her work after Boolie comes in.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: How are you feeling, Mama?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Not a good question to ask somebody nearly ninety.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: Well, you look fine.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: It's my ageless appeal.

dialogues.speaker: . BOOLIE
dialogues.text: Miss McClatchey gave me your message.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Florine is invited, too.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I guess Hoke should drive us. There'll be a crowd.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: Mama, we have to talk about this.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Talk about what?

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: The feasibility of all this.

dialogues.speaker: . DAISY
dialogues.text: Fine, you drive. I thought I was being helpful.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: You know, I believe Martin Luther King has done some mighty fine things.  90.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Boolie, if you don't want to go, why don't you just come right out and say so?

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: I want to go. You know how I feel about him.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Of course, but Florine --

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: Florine has nothing to do with it. I still have to conduct business in this town.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I see. The Werthan Company will go out. of business if you attend the King dinner.

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: Not exactly. But a lot of men I do business with wouldn't like it. They might snicker a little and call me Martin Luther Werthan behind my back -- something like that. And I'd begin to notice that my banking business wasn't being handled by the top dogs. Maybe I wouldn't hear about certain lunch meetings at the Commerce Club. And Jack Raphael, over at Ideal Press, he's a New York Jew instead of a Georgia Jew and the really smart Jews come from New York, don't they? So some of the boys might start throwing business to Jack instead of old Martin Luther Werthan. I don't know. Maybe it wouldn't happen, but that's the way it works. If we don't use those seats, somebody else will and the good Dr. King will never know the difference, will he?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: If we don't use those seats? I'm not supposed to go either?

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: Mama, you can do whatever you want.

dialogues.speaker: . DAISY
dialogues.text: Thanks for your permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something? When did you get so fired up about Martin Luther King? Time was, I'd have heard a different story.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Why, Boolie! I've never been prejudiced and you know it!

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: Okay. Why don't you ask Hoke to go to the dinner with you? DAISY . Hoke? Don't be ridiculous! He wouldn't go!

dialogues.speaker: BOOLIE
dialogues.text: Ask him and see. ON DAISY'S FACE, looking up from her desk, clearly challe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wallpaper is the same as we last saw (before the trip Mobile) but a little blotched and spotted in places. A co of the framed photographs on the wall are a little crooke new color TV set sits on a metal stand, looking out of pl Daisy is reflected in the mirror above her bureau. The sa mirror as at the beginning of the picture, but, of course is twenty years older. Her mind is as sharp as ever, but body is becoming difficult to operate. She is in the proc of putting on the final touches of her evening outfit. Sh takes a final check in the mirror, not especially happy w the results, and heads out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A new sink/dishwasher combination is installed. Otherwise room is the same. Hoke sits at the kitchen table. He wear thickish glasses now and is squinting at the evening pape Daisy enters the kitchen, having added a light jacket to outfit.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: All right. Hoke rises, following her out the back door, remembering turn out the kitchen light as he leaves.  92.
